Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical: This award by the Biomaterials Program in the Division of Materials Research to Emory University is to develop hybrid biotic/abiotic functional materials that will achieve light driven, multi-electron chemistry. Two essential features of living systems are self organization of complex structures and the associated compartmentalization of function, enabling them to extract energy from the environment and store it as fuel used to power all life processes. This proposal seeks to mimic these essential characteristics of living systems by developing artificial materials that use biotic/abiotic interfaces to enable efficient harvesting of light energy and its storage as fuel in high energy density chemical bonds. The proposed work will develop a new class of biotic/abiotic materials based on the integration of nano-structured semiconductor materials, so-called quantum dots, with enzyme biocatalysts. The quantum dots are designed to efficiently collect light and in the process generate electrons that can be used for doing chemistry. The biocatalyst efficiently generates the fuel hydrogen from water when given a ready supply of electrons. The unique properties of the biological catalyst (self assembly and the ability to tailor the interface by structural evolution) will be used to properly wire the two components together into a hybrid material that is stable, robust and efficient at converting light into hydrogen fuel. This project also provides a unique training opportunity for high school and undergraduate students because it integrates multiple disciplines, including molecular biophysics, spectroscopy and materials science, to solve a problem of direct practical relevance.

Technical: Storing light energy in high energy density chemical bonds requires new functional materials to achieve: 1) efficient light harvesting; 2) long-lived charge separation; 3) interfacial charge transfer to a catalyst; and 4) robust catalysts for multi-electron chemistry. The proposal is to develop hybrid materials that integrate a light harvesting and charge separation component with a highly efficient biocatalyst. The specific objectives are: 1) to design, synthesize and characterize hybrid hydrogenase:quantum dot functional materials; 2) to determine the interfacial structures and dynamics that affect function; and 3) to develop photo-electrodes based on the hybrid materials that are capable of light driven hydrogen production. A major challenge is the inherent single electron nature of photosensitizers, which has been the primary limitation of their efficient application to light driven redox chemistry. The proposed work will test whether quantum confined semiconductor materials are capable of acting as multi-electron photosensitizers, by generating and harvesting multiple excitons to drive catalytic chemistry. The proposed work will serve as a foundation for teaching and training students highly interdisciplinary skills in molecular biophysics, spectroscopy and materials science, through the Emory Chemistry Intern Program for high school students, and the Emory Summer Undergraduate Research Experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Enough solar energy strikes the earth’s surface in one hour to power our nation for an entire year. Efficient technologies such as photovoltaic panels exist for converting solar energy into more useful forms such as electricity, the problem is how to store solar energy for use when the sun isn’t shining. Solar water splitting to produce hydrogen fuel is an attractive approach to solar energy storage. The reduction of protons from water to hydrogen in the absence of a catalyst is prohibitively slow, and yet the most effective man-made catalyst is made from platinum, a rare and expensive metal. Better catalysts are found in nature, specifically the hydrogenase enzymes that use commonly available base metals (nickel and iron) to catalyze highly efficient hydrogen production (turnover frequency of 1000 H2 molecules produced per second). The overall objective of this grant was to develop hybrid photocatalysts for light driven hydrogen production that integrate quantum confined nanocrystalline semiconductor materials with hydrogenase enzymes, as shown in the Figure. The quantum rod absorbs light from the sun and generates electrons that are funnelled to the enzyme. The enzyme then reduces protons to hydrogen, forming gas bubbles that are easily collected.

We succeeded in synthesizing and characterizing new hybrid materials based on the design shown in the Figure. These remarkable hybrid photocatalysts achieve an internal quantum efficiency as high as 77% for hydrogen production, meaning each photon absorbed produces and electron and 77% of those electrons are used to convert protons to hydrogen. What makes this even more significant is that this high efficiency was achieved without using a noble metal catalyst and under very mild conditions at near neutral pH in water.  Furthermore, we observe very high enzyme turnover numbers (TON > 106), meaning each enzyme can catalyze production of more than a million hydrogen molecules without being inactivated. Thus, the hybrid photocatalysts are both remarkably efficient compared to what has been achieved previously (20%) and highly robust. Another major challenge addressed by the work is the role of the enzyme:quantum-rod interface in controlling the electron and proton transfer reactions integral to efficient photocatalysis. We have systematically investigated how to control and optimize this interface for efficient function of the hybrid materials. We have also worked how how the hydrogenase enzymes achieve remarkable control of proton and electron transfer reactions through a proton-coupled electron transfer mechanism. Since electron and proton transfer steps are the most basic chemical steps required for the synthesis of all chemical fuels, the understanding provided by this grant of how these steps are achieved in the hydrogenases should have a broad impact in the design of catalysts for making solar fuels.
